instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_TCK: What is SMC_TCK? SMC_TCK is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TDI: What is SMC_TDI? SMC_TDI is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TMS: What is SMC_TMS? SMC_TMS is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TDO: What is SMC_TDO? SMC_TDO is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Water damaged. Arrived with no light on charger. Replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.  Reballed original SMC but no change. Also replaced SMC from donar but still no change. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V. There was no water damage in SMC area

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.22V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V.
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42v

Should SMC be replaced again from another donar or should something else be checked first?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Sounds like bad SMC to me. JTAG removed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Yes JTAG is removed. Will replace SMC again tomorrow then.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Post diode mode and voltage on SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.
Check if <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> is good.
Did you try SMC bypass mode?
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Second SMC replacement was no change

0.490  490 SCL   SDA lines  3.4V   3.4V

<RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> good

have not  tried SMC bypass since there is no light on charger

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3V

<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>  0.108V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
error in measurements

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0.412v  diode 0.346

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 0.120V diode 0.358

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>  0V. Maby replace <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> since SMC already replaced?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> steady high?
If yes, try other SMC...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Yes <SIGNAL>SMC_RESEL_L</SIGNAL> is a steady 3.4V

Replaced SMC again from another donar but still no change.

Replaced again once again after that (4th SMC now) but this time from a board that had other issues but still gave a green light. STILL no change or light. Something else must be causing SMC not to function.

Any other ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Check the 4 <SIGNAL>SMC_TXX</SIGNAL> lines on page 37.
Also check <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> presence.
Diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_TCK</SIGNAL> 3.4v

<SIGNAL>SMC_TMS</SIGNAL> 3.4v

<SIGNAL>SMC_TDO</SIGNAL> 3.4v

<SIGNAL>SMC_TDI</SIGNAL> 3.4v

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> 1.118v

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0.486

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Anything else I can check or is this a no fix?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Remove SMC and check trace continuity for <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> to <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: I would kill for all those SMC chips!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Removed SMC and continiuity to <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> and <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is good. Soldered SMC back but same results.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Remove <RESISTOR>R8140</RESISTOR> and check again <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> voltage.
Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?

Be sure not short on 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>, or other rail.
Is SMC detects a problem, can pull dowsn <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> for protection reason.
Check for pulse on it (and also 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>) when you connect the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
No change in <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> with <RESISTOR>R8140</RESISTOR> removed

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0.256V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 0V

no shorts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Did you check for pulse at the moment charger is connected???
